model_output:
Knowledge representation in expert systems refers to the methodology used to structure and encode human expertise within these AI-based systems [1]. The theoretical foundations of knowledge representation are rooted in the creation of specialized domain knowledge through the process known as knowledge engineering, which involves acquiring knowledge from various sources such as periodicals, books, or interviews with domain experts [1]. Historically, expert systems emerged around mid-1970s under the umbrella of Artificial Intelligence [1]. Initially, these systems relied on heuristic and empirical knowledge [1]. However, future developments might include building expert systems using functional and causal models that incorporate a variety of representations [1]. The evolution of definitions for knowledge representation in expert systems has been closely linked to the development of various examples of expert systems. For instance, MYCIN was an early medical expert system [1], while ACE, EURISKO, and CADHELP were examples in electronics [1]. Connections between expert systems and artificial neural networks have also been explored for classification tasks [1]. References:
[1] Expert_Systems.pdf (2016)
